column41: and slightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is fantastic. Minimal warming alcohol for 6%. Overall this is an outstanding Irish red ale! All around awesome complexity and robustness of dark/bready/light roast malts and mild fruity yeast/earthy hop flavors; very smooth and refreshing to drink with the minimally bitter/drying finish. Very clean and rich malt complexity; with mild fruity yeast and earthy hops against sweetness. A highly enjoyable offering

column4: visible carbonation and a light tan head. The head is very light and soapy. It very quickly fades down to just a very thin wispy layer. Lacing is minimal and slick. The aroma hit me with a light waft of raspberry candy as I opened the bottle. In the glass and with a proper inspection I get the same raspberry candy but with notes of honey and biscuit like malt. The flavor is very much the same as the aroma. It has a light body with a sweet malty character. There are notes of sweet honey and sweet/tart raspberry with hop flavor way off in the distance. The hop flavor just kind of picks up on the tartness of the berry and adds a very mellow subdued bitterness to the finish. Its palate feels light and silky with light somewhat fizzy carbonation.

column2: Trinidad & Tobago;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Carib Brewery;Very refreshing. Easy drinking. Nothing harsh or off putting. Very smooth and enjoyable Caribbean style lager. Would definitely get it again. Cheers.

Trinidad & Tobago;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Carib Brewery;I’m gonna go out on a limb here and say this is one of the two or three best beers you find in the Caribbean. Essentially it’s similar to Corona in terms of it being a skunk macro lager in a clear bottle which is a real shame because it looks very much like piss. If you can get past that this is a very good beer to bring to the beach in the West Indies where they have it in the regular 330mm bottles. The best part is you can get yourself a 6pack of these for around 4 euros and crush them all while on the beach. Have encountered these in Anguilla and SXM but also in Belize where it comes in those comically small bottles about the size of my finger. Not better than Belikin however.

United States;IPA;Bullfrog Brewery;I should preface this by saying that I am quite a hophead. According to the bartender the hop profile of this one had been changed for this batch so the commercial description may no longer be accurate. This beer is a hop lovers dream. Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a hazy caramel color with a small white head. The aroma is a stron g assault of floral and fruity hops. The flavor is also massively strong with fruity and floral hops with a sweet rich malty undertone. I was really impressed with this one and look forward to having it again.

column6: lemons. T - Bitter grassy and floral hops off the start. Grainy phenolic band aid flavor. Lemony yeast. Very faint malt peeking out. The finish is dry with an aftertaste of grassy hops and slightly citrus. This is a hop intensive blonde. In fact it’s a little unbalanced. The bold hops are welcomed upfront. It carries through but steps on everything else. The slight malt is not enough to hold up to the amount of hops. Having said that I still like it. Mouthfeel is spot on. column3: United States;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Founders Brewing Company (Mahou San Miguel);Bottle: Courtesy of wolhfs. Rather sweet with a pretty big yeasty aroma which is quite suprising from a pale lager. Pours a transparent orangish-gold with a big soapy large bubbled white head with some decent retention. Flavor is rather sweet with some light yeatiness. No hops at all and the flavor is pretty consistant from start to finish. Maybe it gets a tad yeastier in the finish. I agree with wolhfs on the Belgian similarities. As it warms a little caramel starts to come thru. Not at all what I was expecting from a pale lager. I wonder what this was like fresh.

United States;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Founders Brewing Company (Mahou San Miguel);Bottle found from the bottom dusty shelf in a party store. Big release of pressure when opened. Large white head erupts when the liquid hits the glass. Opaque light amber color with chunks of floaties. Sweet aroma
column4: caramelish with a touch of yeast. This is reminding me of a belgian more and more. Very carbonated. Lighter bodied. Sweet flavor with hints of sour poking through. Slightly drying. Interesting to see what a few years will do to a pale ale. Different bottle. The previous bottle seemed to be infected so here is an updated rant. Less head although still forms and leaves good lacing. Predominantly malty in aroma with a touch of sweetness. A little bit of stale aroma sneaks in. Still somewhat drying. This has lost all of it’s noble hop power but is still pleasant. Numbers reflect non-infected bottle.

column3: United States;Weissbier - Hefeweizen;Hereford & Hops Restaurant & Brew Pub;On-tap at the brewpub: Straw gold carpeting of color with a sparkly white cap of medium height. Moderate lacing in spots and broken sheeting. Keeps a good skim the whole time. Aroma is quite plain. Just a small smacking of wheat induced incense and a smearing of tartly set lemon. Flavors bring the same tame action of low leveled wheat and a short tone of lemon spritz. Nothing to it really. Very average if not all together forgetful on the buds. Feel is just as lack luster. Smooth but plain and lacking any real hefe verve or qualities that should be in a hefe. Where’s the action? One of only a couple from Hereford’s that are a bit hard to get down and don’t make the cut.

I like my Irish reds with with a nice smooth creamy body and this one just doesn’t have it. O- Its very easy to drink and somewhat enjoyable. Whoa...this is down right awful. Major raspberry abstract just flys up the nostrils with carbonation that could put ginger ale to shame. column6: as one may expect from the nose
column7: is a bit on the drier and maltier side. It begins with a little bit of caramel sweetness mixed with a nice roasted malt and crackery flavored base. As the flavor advances
column8: the caramel fades while some spice flavors of some nutmeg coming to the tongue. The roasted flavors increase to some extent with a little bit of some other lightly sweetened fruit flavors of apple and pear mixing in. In the end
column9: a grassy and herbal hop flavor develop giving it just the right hint of bitterness to create an overall roasty and still moderately drier malty flavor on the tongue. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is average in terms of thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is rather average. Both are appropriate for the style and make for a rather easy drinking Oktoberfest. Overall – A rather decent Oktoberfest overall. A little more on the maltier side with a decent balance of spice and roast to create an enjoyable beer overall.

United States;Helles / Dortmunder Export;Pennsylvania Brewing Company;DATE: September 3
column4: 2016... OCCASION: Penn State kicks off its season hosting Kent State--a beautiful fall day deserves a quality Pennsylvania beer... GLASSWARE: Penn State pilsner... pours a clear gold with moderate effervescence... a thick off-white head settles to suds... bubbles pocket the ring around the glass... not too much to look at... a beautiful metallic hop/bread malt balance erupts... soft flowery hops and a bit of citrus
column5: but the malts are what makes this an alluring fall beer... the palate is smooth
column7: mild at the throat with enough buzz at the teeth... a mild aftertaste that is refreshing
column8: and one that encourages the next sip--outstanding for its style... a pleasant sweetness pervades the experience
column12: and dough making for a full flavor profile despite its drinkability... this beer is a great compliment to the day
column13: very light ABV but flavorful and balanced... indeed a medal winner
column14: and one I plan to session throughout the evening... and
column16: WOW--who is sleeping on this beer? What are helles drinkers expecting? Check Beeradvocate for what’s up...

column3: United States;Flavored - Other;Bell's Brewery;From Jan 2008 I got this as an extra in a great trade with hoppymeal. Thanks Derek! This pours from 12oz bottle a very dark brown with about a 1/2 head of tannish foam. Still enough foam to put some nice lacing on my glass. The smell..well
column4: I got a good whiff as soon as I popped the cap. Caramel malt and dark fruit hit my nose buds in abundance. The nose reminds me of a good English BWSA. The taste has a huge caramel malt profile and is delish! That caramel is followed by some very nice dark fruit character in the way of raisin and plum and fig. Wow. This is one tasty brew. It has a medium to medium thick mouthfeel and it finishes with that caramel malt/dark fruit goodness. Hell of a sipper in my book and the alcohol just shows up as some warming after the swallow. It's most welcome for this rather cold snowy day here in Casper. Btw
column5: there *is* some bitterness here that I notice mostly when I swish the beer in my mouth and it's a dark chocolate bitterness. Very nice and a good balancing factor to the caramel malt sweetness. I think Bell's did themselves proud with this brew and I wouldn't hesitate to drinking this one again! Thanks again
column6: Derek! My taste buds are very happy right now.

The nose is mild and is largely saaz hoppiness. Body light and mouthfeel thin. The flavor is floral hops with some graininess. The finish is lightly bitter. Solid example of the style.
United States;Pilsener / Pils / Pilsner;Rockfish Grill & Anacortes Brewery;Saaz and doughy aroma. Pours brilliant and bright
column4: thin quickly dissipating head. Crackers and light grassiness in aroma. Well balanced yet lacking in malt richness. Finish is a bit weak and could use more malt backbone and slightly higher carbonation. Missing that melanoidin rich character. Otherwise a drinkable Bopils and a good showing for a place that focuses on ale production.

column3: United States;Pilsener / Pils / Pilsner;Rockfish Grill & Anacortes Brewery;On tap at the brewpub/restaurant pouring up deep gold with micro thin white head. The aroma is mild and is largely noble like hoppiness. The taste is floral
column4: some spicy hops and a moderate level of malts to grainy like malts. I love the balance where the hops are punchy and crisp and remain out of reach of the sweet maltiness. I get a pleasing floral to spicy hop flavor lingering into the after taste. Darn hoppy and darn tasty pils. Nice job.

column3: United States;Stout;Rockfish Grill & Anacortes Brewery;Here is another Northwest nitro stout that surpasses usual expectiations - reminds me of the LaConner nitro Imperial Stout. Wonderfully creamy head
column4: thicker than latte foam and almost as milky. Sweet aroma
column5: soft chocolate and roasted malts - with all that cream it reminds a bit of chocolate milk. I usually like to play grown-up and cast off these sweet beers as lacking depth
column6: but this beer is just wonderfully crafted. The insatiable creaminess lays a smooth foundation for the mild roasted malt and smooth chocolate to flow on
column7: sliding around all parts of the tongue on down the throat with ease. A slight bitterness in the malt is a slight distraction in the flavor
column8: but despite this the palate here is sheer perfection. A dessert beer for sure - ends the evening wonderfully.

column4: but I will add my two cents on what was there.. ----------------Dark black color. Medium head. Aroma is malty and choclately. A light bodied stout. I think this bottle is infected as I am picking up a lactic wine like quality that shouldn’t be here. Malts are roasted and a touch chocolate. Hops and other qualities are masked by the sourness. column3: United States;Stout;Greenshields Brewery & Pub;Pitch black beer - no light escapes at all. Mocha chocolate colored head
column4: smallish really but decent retention. 1st pass - muted coffee tones mixed with red wine. Not real agressive given the bold appearance. 2nd pass - still laying kind of flat expecting the aroma to jump out. Somewhat disappointing. 3rd pass - some malt hints trying to escape but still essentially dead. Time to taste this bad boy. good mouthfeel- there is real body here. The flavor on entry is straight ahead coffee that dissolves into a winey fruitiness at mid-palate. finish is strong and clean. Not the best stout but certainly among the better.

column1: Flying Goose Split Rock Golden Ale;New London
column3: United States;Blonde Ale / Golden Ale;Flying Goose Brew Pub;"""I’m not a fan of ales. This beer was memorable despite the taste let down but I’d love to stop by for another. A - Poured into a pint glass with a 3 finger head. They call it Golden Ale with good reason as cloudy gold liquid barely let any light through. The head subsided slowly. S - The smell was sweet with traces of pine and marshmallows. Lavender also hit my nose. T - If the taste matched the smell
column4: I’d be leaving a more positive review. A mix between Budweiser and Yuengling with traces of a great beer buried between the two. Low ABV and very light hops meant the beer wasn’t full by any means and left me unsatisfied with the residual tastes staying around for a while long after I finished swallowing. M - Carbonation explodes with one swish and sticks around for a while. I enjoyed the mouthfeel if only it tasted better. O - I’d get the beer again if my entree was a plate of chicken wings or cheese fries. I wasn’t too impressed with it but
column5: as another reviewer mentioned
column7: avoiding the 9%+ ABV beers is probably a good idea. For a low ABV beer that’s light on the stomach
column10: this wouldn’t be my first choice out of their selection of 15 on tap."""

column3: United States;Pale Ale - American / APA;Flying Goose Brew Pub;Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a light amber to orange sort of color with a small off white foamy head that slid off pretty quick. The aroma had some semi-sweet and dried biscuit to white bread notes up front and having a little bit of floral to grassy hops underneath. The flavor had that same sort of dried biscuit/bready sweet maltiness all throughout with a light aftertaste. Finish was all about the breadiness. The palate was between light and medium bodied with a decent sessionability about it. Fairly low carbonation and an ABV that felt appropriate. Overall
column4: not much of an APA
column5: but also not exactly a top notch beer. It’s just an all around drinker easy to take down with food.

column3: United States;IPA;Oregon Trail Brewery;Pours a fiery golden copper color. Clear. Lazy carbonation floats to the surface. Off-white creamy head forms easily and leaves a wet sloppy doily of lace behind. Pleasant aromas of juicy grapefruity citrus flesh along with the bitter rind. Deep inhalations reward you with sweet caramel square notes. An occasional flare-up of alcohol is noted. Maltiness is not shy here at the beginning. A blast of molten caramel and the warm homey feel of bread dough. Citrus hops kick in to give their two cents. Bitter (almost too bitter) rind tones appear. The initial malty creaminess that was welcomed is soon beaten about the face and head by a trifle unbalanced nature. (I shudder to think what this would be like if the initial maltiness was weaker.) Too bitter. Too rough. Needed a little bit of caressing to meld the characteristics. As it stands now it’s just too disjointed. I’ll try next month it will prob smooth out.
United States;IPA;Oregon Trail Brewery;This has got very generous portions of hops

column3: United States;IPA;Oregon Trail Brewery;Draft at the brewery. What I would called an American-British hybrid IPA with a homebrew flavor. Full to medium bodied with a slightly rough texture - and like I said

I'm on the last third of my glass now and the tastes just seem to get better and better as this liquid nectar warms up even more from the body heat transmitted from my hand to the glass. Wow
column10: just wow. As I take my last sip

column12: I realize that I've just had a thoroughbly enjoyable drinking session with one

There is a solid sweet roasted malty character with a good balance of toasted bready notes and dark roasted bitter coffee notes. The palate has a solid medium feel with mellow balanced carbonation.

column5: but wouldnâ€™t pay for it again. Almost like your first homebrew you ever made. Not sure how they have been brewing as long as they have and the beer is as good as my first college homebrew? Maybe I brewed really well the first time. Also not fully convinced this was the pale ale. Could have been but the cherry aspects make me think maybe it was actually the black cherry weizen (which they said they were out of). Or maybe the cherry aspect was from the malt (like caramelized maltiness but the soapy character made if seem a little cherry cough syrup like??) Not convinced it would have been rated much different so I am rating it under what I was told the beer was. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column3: United States;Bock - Doppelbock;Wagner Valley Brewing Company;Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a mug. The label has no freshness date or abv%. Appearance: Looking into the glass I am presented with a deep garnet red brew with good clarity and a tall off white to light tan head. This head slowly fades out leaving some spotty lacing at the top of the glass. Smell: There is a big rich malty character coming out of the glass. In it I get candy sweet notes like a grape sucker or grape soda. This is backed up with a big bready sweet maltiness Taste/Palate: The big malty sweetness from the aroma hits the tongue with candy like grape notes inside of a somewhat modest medium to full bodied bready sweetness. In the back ground there are some very subdued hop notes that offer a touch of herbal leafy spice with almost no bitterness. The palate is very smooth and lightly carbonated. Its sweetness sticks on the palate a bit but not in a heavy or to cloying a way. Notes: It’s not the most complex Doppelbock but there is something about its basic character that I like and find enjoyable to drink.

A pretty noncomplex stout that is easy drinking but lacks real character...at least for me. Bottom line: Nothing really bad about this brew but there's not a whole lot going on. column1: Uinta Anglers Pale Ale;Salt Lake City
column3: United States;Pale Ale - American / APA;Uinta Brewing Company;From Jan 2007 Poured from 12oz bottle a hazy medium gold with a large head of foam that hangs around for the entire session as a solid layer with lots of lacing. The smell has a nice strong air of caramel malt. The taste is big on the caramel malt up front with a nice hop bitterness in the background that balances the sweetness nicely. I can also taste some graininess in between that adds some good complexity to this Pale Ale. The finish is on the bitter side and invites one to enjoy another sip. Good stuff. Bottom line: A very nice APA that fits the style well. I recommend it. Thanks to Wasatch for another sample of brews from Utah!

It has a really nice toffee biscuit malt aroma with some peppery spicy hop notes. Medium bodied and surprisingly dry and fruity. The taste starts off malty sweet but then gets lots of raisins and stone fruits before finishing crisp and dry. A good beer to pair with lunch. In my case yakitori tare... my favorite of three red ales... it beat out Lompoc Proletariat Red and Ballast Point California Amber. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It also pairs well in almost any sampler try to calibrate your own opinions on this regional brewpub. AROMA / APPEARANCE Wheat
column7: and cloudy hops haze the air with a yeasty profile that borders on citrus zest. Melted lemon custard fills the glass along with light slippery legs. FLAVOR / PALATE Lemon custard
column9: and hay imbue the first impressions with a semisweet balanced texture. The chewy finish refreshes as it transitions to the back of the throat. Overall there's nothing remarkable about this hefeweizen but it does serve its purpose well as a safe fallback for any situation.

column1: Great Dane Old Glory American Pale Ale;Madison
column3: United States;Pale Ale - American / APA;Great Dane Pub & Brewery;On tap in Fitchburg
column4: WI The final entry in the evening flight contained the last of the Dane's regular taps. A fairly proficient pale ale
column5: this particular pour follows the template of the rest. A good benchmark for what a traditional pale ale should be provides the chance to compare your own tastes against a regional standby. AROMA / APPEARANCE Malt driven earthiness encrusted with crisp hops that dance over the glass liven this bright profile. A lazy snowy head takes its time melting into the carbonated bronze core. FLAVOR / PALATE Nutty hops rest on a bed of fresh caramel. The cooler nature of this offers a seamless transition to some of the Great Dane's less hoppy offerings. A moderate finish caps off a balanced approach which will make you pleased that Happy Hour lasts for another thirty minutes. If I had to choose from their daily drinkers this would be my fallback.

column3: United States;Weissbier - Kristallweizen;J.T. Whitneys Pub & Brewery;"On tap at brewpub I stopped here on whim just to get dinner. When I say this on the taplist I knew it was worth trying
column4: even if turned out to be a disappointment. After all how many times do you run across a Kristallweizen made by a brewer in Wisconsin with ties to Germany? Aroma / Appearance - I should knock off a point for coming with a lemon wedge but that was my fault for not having the foresight to ask them to leave it off. Fresh banana blended with Pedro’s orange degreaser. It was not strong though; imagine running it through a coffee filter to supress the strength. A hint of wheat was evident after some concentration. The body was ga transparent golden yellow with no cloudiness. This is likely due to the filtering which you ddon’t get with a good hefe. Flavor / Palate - The mouthfeel was satisfying but not exceptionally thick even for a wheat beer. A slight sourness permeated the orange and banana notes. Everything was offset by the taste of slightly stale white bread. It was very easy to drink; I had no problems finishing it off. I wouldn’t say it was an amazing beer but I could drink this if it were the only non-macro option at a party."

column3: Germany;Pilsener / Pils / Pilsner;Friesisches Brauhaus zu Jever (Radeberger Gruppe);"""Jever"" is very similar beer with ""Carlsberg Pilsner"".. The taste and the malty aftertaste is almost the same.. Small difference exist here between these two famous beers. Also remind me the ""Asahi Super dry"" beer little bit.. Anyway this beer is very refreshing and also little slightly light.. Has very hoppy flavour and some extra malty dry bitterness in the aftetaste that is the best thing about these beers. Overall one very refreshing beer to drink. For the style is very good but personal i prefer little more the ""Carlsberg"" over this one.."

column3: Australia;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;James Boag (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings);4.7%ABV. Pale lager. Tapped out a light amber blonde. 6°SRM. Nose has some light beery very slightly yeasty aromas. Very pleasing. Easy to see why this is the most popular beer in Tassie. Nice laager type nose with clean sweet malt and grain aromas. No ester-like funk in the nose. Its somehow sweeter and cleaner and with less character at the same time. Clearly well-provisioned
column4: just a function of which yeast is doing what to the malty sugars. Mouthfeel is carbonated. Sudsy. Palate is sweet malt. Barley bread with some nice toffee notes. Not too complex
column5: but a very straightforward honest taste experience
column6: much like the people of western Tasmania. No need for elaborate pretentions. Bitter sweet finish with slightly more hop character than expected in a straight lager. Clean finish
column7: very pleasing. Goes on the list for being an honest straight up well-provisioned commercial brew. Goes on Favorites List!

column2: Barbados;Radler / Shandy;Banks Barbados Brewery;"One of the best shandys I've ever had. In fact
column3: it was my first Shandy I ever tried. I was 14 or 15 and on holiday in Barbados. Convinced my parents to let me try it and it was amazing. No shandy can beat this Banks Twist Shandy. Banks is the best Caribbean beer so of course Banks Twist will be great ;) It is quite lemonade- foward so if you prefer a more beer flavour then this shandy will probably be too sweet for you. But if you're like me and like it tasting 50/50
column4: do try it next time you're in the Caribbean! I really don't understand why so many people are leaving half bad reviews. If you don't like sweet drinks then don't buy a Shandy.. Just buy a beer or something else! Saying it's 'too sweet' is ridiculous considering it's HALF LEMONADE

Canada;Flavored - Fruit;Alley Kat Brewing Company;Valemount 17/7 2018. 34
column4: 1 cl bottle from The Wine Merchant
column5: Jasper. Simple orange label where I can get an understanding that this beer have a thing for apricot. Pours clear golden yellow with medium-sized white head. Settles as thin remnants of foam. No Lacing. Aroma is heavy with apricot essence. Sweet and cloying and artificial. It is so dominant that it overcomes any other odors. Light carbonation. Slightly thick texture. Flavor is heavy sweet. No discernible bitterness. Aftertaste is sweet. Lingering for a unpleasantly long time. A heavy handed effort by dumping a serious dose of apricot essence into a beer that result in what is closer to a way too sweet Dessert Wine than a beer. But fair enough: The name of this beer was a fair warning.

column1: Alley Kat Full Moon Pale Ale;Edmonton
column3: Canada;Pale Ale - American / APA;Alley Kat Brewing Company;Appearance: Pours a gorgeous orange body with a decent white head floating on top. Lots of lacing left on the sides. Smell: A good piney hop aroma with some solid malt. More on the dry side. Taste: At first i thought it was a little off but as it warms it does get better. More malt-driven that hops though the flavor of the hops (grapefruit) are quite present with a present but not overdone bitterness. Mouthfeel: Dry and a tiny bit metallic. As it warms it gets smoother but feels a little bit thin and light. Carbonation is spot on but something about the mouthfeel keeps it at average.

column3: England;Bitter - Premium / Strong / ESB;Nethergate Brewery;What the hell! They bamboozled me into buying an esb! Busted this out and took a sip I was all huh.... Not as bad as others. Skunky but not terrible. Nops lingers but not terrible. Lemon note on the back of the throat. Palate is smooth. A little stale tasting like how the esb do. Overall this is a pretty enjoyable esb. Not my favorite style but I think it will surpass drain pour.

column4: but I got an old bottle of this in a trade (which had majorly turned) and between that and the fact that I drank about a zillion of these when I first got the stout bug I feel confident I’m not doing the beer a disservice. It’s very similar to many of the tropical stouts and I’m sure they used sugars to give it the molasses and raisin flavors it possessed. It had a very low roast/burnt profile and was much more geared toward sweetness like Belco Stout. It did have some nice drawn out raisin and prune notes ala Anchor Porter
column5: but again with little roast to rein it in.

column3: Canada;Pale Ale - English;Nelson Brewing Company (Canada);Awesome aroma. Full
column4: deep and rich hops that truly make clear the use of whole leaf hops in this one. Lush forest moss and evening sweet grass everywhere. Hands down one of the best noses I have come across. The forest moss follows directly into the mouth and though the hops fade a bit
column5: they remain prominent. A little more malted barley mid-palate to accompany the bitterness would have really put this one among the elite. A little bit too soft in the mouth. Finish is dry but shows hints of brown sugar and surely closes the book on a delicious hops adventure.

column3: Canada;IPA;Nelson Brewing Company (Canada);A sleeper
column4: for me at least. Nelson Brewing’s been around since 1991 and I hadn’t had anything of theirs for a long time. Last summer I found a few bottles of Paddywhack IPA in a friend’s cabin fridge and was blown away. A great Pacific Northwest style IPA
column5: right in the sweet spot between wimpy IPA’s in name only
column6: and the monstrous high-alcohol super-hopped mega-IPA’s so many breweries have been putting out the past few years. Those are showy
column7: gaudy freak shows (albeit often yummy) compared to solid class and balance of this Paddywhack IPA. Which is not to say it’s mild -- you get that wonderful full blast of aromatic
column8: citrusy Pacific Northwest hops which marks this style
column9: grounded by a just-right mouth bitteness and comparatively light malty body. It’s similar to Central City’s phenomenal Red Racer India Pale Ale
column10: not just in style (they’re both classic expressions of the Pacific Northwest IPA) but also in quality. Yes
column11: I said it! This is an unduly overlooked long-standing gem of the BC craft brewing scene which deserves to be rediscovered.

The draft version is far ’Superior’ than the bottled/canned offerings. Nothing like getting a ’large’ at Time Out in the Soo. (a large is a 32 oz mug) To sum up
column4: while this beer is a bit nostalgic for me and my past visits to the Soo
column5: I really enjoy the light refreshing nature of this brew and the very smooth and creamy aftertaste. I can’t understand why the negative reviews. Try it on tap before you pass judgement.

column1: Northern Breweries Superior Lager;Sault Ste. Marie
column3: Canada;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Northern Breweries;"When Doran’s owned the ""soo"" brewery they produced a northern tavern grog labeled ""Doran’s lager"". Other offerings from the old brewery were Doran’s ’55’ and silver spray lager. The recipe for this superior lager seems to have the same peculiar hopping and malt mix that made Doran’s lager a staple of the northern lakeshore taverns in the 60s and 70s
column4: but the process must have changed because this beer is not crystal clear. This rendition by Northen brewery is called “superior” lager: Pours a murky pale gold color
column5: slight hints of hops and a sour yeasty smell to the nose
column7: mouth feel has a light- body heavy on the hops with some undecernable flavors (corn? rice?) and a finish punctuated by yeast….which isn’t filtered very well.....the haze could be protiens as this was served very cold. A local drink for the deck of the laker or salmon boats that cruise south Superior and the 3-brand-taverns proliferating the superior Canuck shore....and little else. 2 0r 3 is enough! I drink this stuff when I go north to the salmon or moose camp…… for a nostalgia thing...gives you a sense of where you are
column8: it’s a northern Ontario tradition.. I bought some down south here and it hasn’t the same impact as when you’re chugging one staring at superior’s craggy shoreline from a trolling salmon boat.. On the patio in an urban T’ranna pub it seems out of place…………and rightfully so…..this is a logger’s lager. Just recently had this beer on tap at the Lakeside hotel in Wawa northern Ontario. (say hi to Woody for me if you drop in) I revised my ratings accordingly. This beer was made at Northern’s other plant that kegs draft and it was a good draft beer. I don’t care for it bottled and never in a can. I do recommend the draft version to anyone visiting Northern Ontario who wants to truely experience the ""local flavor""."

column1: Northern Breweries Superior Lager;Sault Ste. Marie

column1: Northern Breweries Superior Lager;Sault Ste. Marie
column3: Canada;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Northern Breweries;Not as bad as Josh said: maybe he had a skunky batch. But definitely a boring lager and nothing superior about it. Brewed in Sudbury as far as I know and not the Sault. Anyway your standard macrobrewed swill - light on malt flavour (ie. light in body) and light in hop character.

column1: Northern Breweries Superior Lager;Sault Ste. Marie
column3: Canada;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Northern Breweries;Awful. Odd fruity taste hints at too high a fermentation temperature. There are some hop flavours
column4: but they mix so poorly with the esters that it actually makes the beer worse. Malt flavours are lacking
column5: body is almost syrupy (for a lager) and the finish is tough to choke back. If you can finish a six-pack
column6: you're a better man than me.

column1: Northern Breweries Northern Ale;Sault Ste. Marie
column3: Canada;Blonde Ale / Golden Ale;Northern Breweries;"I used to drink this in local bars on draught in one of my own gestures to support local business in my town. My rating here is based on timing and there being a fresh batch on tap that delivered its true and best aspects. It had a nice malt-hops aroma and more character than the other macros that were on tap besides it being good value for my hard-earned beer money. Gold body with a nice white head that laced the sides of the pitcher and glass. A likeable pale ale with a light malt taste
column4: an overtone of bread crust
column5: and a bready finish but there was something about it that had a most terrible propensity for the hang-over. At one time a new owner took over and improved on the product -as if the pipes were cleaned up at the brewery
column6: giving the final product an overall better taste and a cleaner finish besides the morning after the night before seeming to be less traumatic. I was saddened to see that the new investor lost his shirt and had to close shop due to there not being enough local support. It was as if the local beer drinkers had a collective vendetta against this ""foreigner"" who came in and tried to make something better out of something the locals should have been proud of. Many locals called it Northern Stale and I partially agree: if you didn’t order it in good timing and/or if the bar you were visiting was eager to sell off a bad or stale keg
column8: the beer drinker were guaranteed a disappointment
column9: and that disappointment got more prevalent the further you were away from where it was made when you ordered Northern on draught. One thing I know about that beer: the draught keg version did not travel well. It was here in Sudbury where the travel distance was shortest between the brewery and the bar that I had my best experiences with this beer on draught. You know what? I miss it."

column1: Northern Breweries Northern Ale;Sault Ste. Marie
column3: Canada;Blonde Ale / Golden Ale;Northern Breweries;This beer used to be on tap from North Bay to Port Arthur all through the 70s when Doran’s made it. Northern ale was the beer they sucked back at the Timmin’s Maple Leaf tavern watching “Stompin’ Tom” come off the floor . This stuffs been around since before the 60s and a couple of generations of Northerners relate to this beer. Since the brewey was taken over and they took their water from different sources
column4: this beer has undergone some periodic changes. What is being offered now is the best they can do with the recipes they have but the process is wanting. This is NOT the Northern that wrested the North Country taverns from Labatts and Molson’s. This stuff pours a pale gold with lots of carbonation. Little suggestion of hop or grain smell.......what I got wafted up with a lot of carbonation and veggies. Light head that leaves quickly. A great tart
column5: crisp start this fades as the palate is filled with a heavy grain-vegetable taste (for a light ale) and a finish that has a lingering sweet-malt taste….not what I like in a light ale. But still better than most Canadian macro ales aimed at the mass market.

column1: Northern Breweries Northern Ale;Sault Ste. Marie

Canada;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Northern Breweries;"Not great

column8: but mostly hay in the aroma. Watery and easily drinkable. I’m not sure where I got this beer... it seems to have materialized out of nowhere on my trip to MN..."

column3: Canada;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Northern Breweries;"Finally got around to tasting this again on a trip west I stopped at the riverfront tavern in Sault St. Marie...last time I had it Dorans ran the brewery. It was aparently named and brewed to commemorate the centennial of the sault locks in 1955....it still retains a hint of the character of the brews of those days that were sold by the tray full in ""soo"" locks River street taverns and Algoma mining town taverns. This is a rough neck lager meant to be swilled by the pitcher full to be sure. Weak straw color but nice malt and grassy hop smells..small white head that laces quickly. Starts crisp and tart builds to a medium malty hop balanced body then the finish is smooth with a lingering malty sweetness....nothing fancy here just a standard Canadian commercial lager the way they were brewed in the 50s and 60s."
Canada;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Northern Breweries;"All things considered
column4: it's a good beer. The ""upper crust micro brewery people"" (no slam intended)probably should avoid this one since it's suited for the average joe not the bottle sniffing

column4: Cambridge Beer Festival
column5: May 2005. You may think May is an unusual time to be drinking a Christmas ale and you’d be right. But this isn’t your average Christmas beer - its been aged in cask since then. And it shows. There is bags of plenty of dried fruit and Christmas pudding. But there’s a woody edge which becomes much more pronounced on the palate. Tastes rather musty and dried out
column6: with a vinous edge. There are vestiges of a warming richness but it’s has ebbed away with age. So it comes over more like an old ale than a barley wine. Interesting but I don’t really think the ageing has done it any favours. I’d like to try it fresh to get a comparison.

column3: England;Strong Ale - English;Gales;I got my hands on this rare gem while working in the beer dept. at The Party Source. It was all alone on the very top of a storage rack and no one knew where it came from and how long it had been there. So I saved it for about another five years and finally decided to try it this past Christmas
column4: unaware of how well it had aged (or soured for that matter.) Poured into a trappist style glass producing a small ring of foam. Tons of UFOs (unidentified floating objects
column5: ) which was probably old
column6: stale yeast. The color was brownish tan almost tobacco-like russet. Aroma was fruity and vinegary
column7: like a very tannic red wine. The body was thin and flat
column8: and the flavor was of immediate sourness
column9: evolving into a medicinal fruitiness. Gales has been one of my favorite English breweries and I only wish that i had tried more from them. Drank this under the Christmas tree with my love. Made it about halfway through the glass before we decided that time and the elements had not been friendly to this beer
column10: which reluctantly became a sink pour...

United States;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Anheuser-Busch InBev (AB InBev);This is my favorite light beer. I first tasted it on a tour at the brewery in St Louis but they informed me it’s only available in the Great Lakes states. Not sold in St Louis! This was in 2004 and I put in repeated requests to have it sold near me. I bought cases of it whenever I was in a market that sold it. Now... 13 years later it is available in Kansas City. I drink a wide variety of beers most of the time but when I want a light beer with low calories and a crisp flavor
column4: I go for Michelob Golden Light.

column3: United States;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Anheuser-Busch InBev (AB InBev);12 ounce bottle. Pours a very clear straw golden color with a quickly disappearing white head. The aroma says it all: this is the perfect example of acetaldehyde
column4: in beer which is the precursor to ethanol in alcoholic fermentation. The aroma and flavor here are of cut green apples. I find this quite offensive and actually worse than most other mainstream light lagers
column5: but I used to own a tavern and I sold a lot of it. One time
column6: my beverage chiller got a bit too cold and Michelob Golden Draft Light froze solid while the Beck´s non-alcoholic right next to it was just fine. That tells you just how thin and watered-down this stuff really is.

column3: United States;Witbier / Belgian White Ale;Southampton Publick House;From Mar 2006 Poured from 22oz bottle(room temp) a straw colour with a smallish head of foam that dissipated quickly. I also note that the carbonation level seems to be very low and that's ok with me. The smell is very spicy with notes of clove as well as some yeasty sourness. The taste has some of the clove noted in the smell but it's pushed into the background while other spices and a yeasty sweet and sour thingy take center stage. The finish is quite spicy and long lasting. Oh yeah
column4: 7%abv eh? Well hidden! Overall
column5: I find the taste different from the Wits I've tried before and in this case
column6: different=it's quite pleasing. Bottom line: An easy drinking Witbier that must make the locals of this brewery very happy on a hot summer day. I recommend it. Thanks again to Nutbrown!

The flavor blended all of the previously mentioned aromas together for the most part and lightly touched the aftertaste. Finish is malty and lenient on the cherry wood. Seemed more like cherry sweetness on the finish. The feel was about medium bodied and punching the carbonation with a little bit of those earthy hops I smelled earlier. ABV felt as projected. Overall

column1: Atlantic SOB Special Old Bitter Ale;Bar Harbor
column3: United States;Bitter - Premium / Strong / ESB;Atlantic Brewing Company;Reviewed from notes. The appearance had a hazy dark brown body with a foamy tan half finger white head that lasts for about a good minute. The body is too hazy for any carbonation to be seen rising and there is minimal lacing. The smell had bitter hops up front with a light bit of malts with an even lighter sense of molasses. The taste was a slight malty sweetness combined nicely with the bitter hops. A slight breadiness comes through as well. On the palate

Palate is medium bodied oily texture average carbonation and a bitter finish. A refreshing and unremarkable pale except for the floating fruit.

column1: Beer Works Bunker Hill Bluebeery Ale;Boston
column3: United States;Flavored - Fruit;Beer Works;16 oz. draft. Clear gold pour with a white head and great retention. Good lacing. Whole blueberries floating up and down in the beer
column4: eventually settling to the bottom. Beer is clean and crisp. Pilsner base? Blueberry flavor is very light. Flavorful real blueberries make a fruity dessert to finish. Well done.

column1: Beer Works Bunker Hill Bluebeery Ale;Boston
column3: United States;Flavored - Fruit;Beer Works;Sampler at Boston Beer works. Pours golden with a white head until they dropped some tiny little blueberries and now it's streaked with blue. Has some berry notes on the nose. A slight tartness on the tongue. I like blueberry flavor but not actually blueberries. It's kind of annoying to try and drink this beer without swallowing a mouthful of berries. It feels like cheating somehow.

column3: United States;BarleyWine / WheatWine / RyeWine;Wild Goose Brewery (National Brewing Company);In the bottle on 11/13/09. Thanks to Dave G. for the beer. Pours a chestnut color with a thin white head. Caramel with a model car cement aroma. At this point in the ten-year old bottle
column4: the malt seems to be gone from the beer. The hops are also gone. This is much more like an old ale than it is a barleywine. The beer is clearly past its prime so my entry essentially represents beer archaeology. It still has a finish of big ethanol on the roof of your mouth. At this juncture I’d have to say it is really good but not great. I wish I’d tried this beer in its prime.

column3: United States;BarleyWine / WheatWine / RyeWine;Wild Goose Brewery (National Brewing Company);(Bottle

column9: wet cardboard and honey. The mouthfeel is numbing from the alcohol and a bit sticky. Honey and dried fruits in the finish. Medium to full bodied. Bit simplistic but enjoyable.

column3: United States;BarleyWine / WheatWine / RyeWine;Wild Goose Brewery (National Brewing Company);12 oz. bottle (Oct. 1999) from Cletus. Pours a mostly clear reddish copper brown with very little head and some floaties. The aroma has over ripe fruit

column9: warming alcohol and a surprising dry and mildly bitter finish. There signs of oxidation were not as much as I expected there would be. I would have liked to have tried this one closer to its release.

column3: United States;Traditional Ale - Other;Wild Goose Brewery (National Brewing Company);This is an ale brewed differently from any you’ve tried before. The label claims it to be a “resurrection of an early brewing technique used in the days before iron kettles.” Super-heated stones are dropped into the wort
column4: as they were when wooden vessels could not be heated by fire. The hot stones carmelize sugars and release toffee-like flavors into the beer. The resulting brew resembles a pale ale
column5: possibly even an IPA
column6: as it is out of balance toward hops rather than malt. Crisp and delicious.

column5: hot rocks were dropped into the wort to heat it and caramelize the sugars

Bottle. 4.70% ABV--16 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) No sediment. Foamy big mild lace white head. Fizzy clear thin straw gold color. Mild hop delicate rye aroma front. column3: Germany;Pilsener / Pils / Pilsner;Dortmunder Actien Brauerei (Radeberger Gruppe);"Vintage bottle purchased at The Stuffed Sandwich
column4: May 2007 This beer pours with an almost clear
column5: dullish amber color. It is almost perfectly still and has no head at all. Aromas of honey-like
column9: prunes and a really accentuated dark fruit character make up the nose. The beer is still quite sweet
column10: despite the age; in fact the oxidation character may have even accentuated the sweetness. This beer has some really interesting aged flavors to it; notes of sherry
column15: and an almost soda like quality (a mix of cream soda along with a hint of cola). This has quite a light mouthfeel
column16: with lots of the heft having dropped out over time. There is a rich
column17: nutty taste here as well. I am really finding the flavors in this clearly aged beer really interesting. I would not have guessed it would have lasted this long; it has morphed into something that is quite flavorful (perhaps even more so than it was initially) without the cardboard-tasting oxidation I would have expected."

column3: United States;Bitter - Premium / Strong / ESB;Great Lakes Brewing (Ohio);It has a large frothy white head that has very good retention and make great rings of lace with each sip. The body has a light honey color with a slight haze. The aroma is wonderful and well balanced. It has sweet bready malt with some buttery notes as well as some fruity notes and mild floral hops in the nose. The flavor matches the aroma with a solid malty base that brings buttery and fruity notes with perfectly balanced hop bitterness and flavor. Some of the fruity notes include elderberry and black currant and the hops give some floral and herbal notes to the party. The palate has a smooth silky texture with soft carbonation

The taste was balanced fairly nicely between the maple and the coffee/chocolate. On the palate

column3: United States;Porter;F.X. Matt Brewing Company;Its body has a brownish color with reddish amber highlights. It produced a light beige
column4: two finger thick head. It is a slow fading head that fades down to a just a ring of lacy foam. Lacing on the glass is spotty and slick. There is a definite sweet maple syrup like aroma with a touch of toasted malt. It has a very sweet mix of thin toasted bready maltiness covered with maple flavored corn syrup. I also get some buttery notes as well. This flavor reminds me of a frozen waffle covered in a Log Cabin like breakfast syrup and butter. This one is all about the sweetness as there is only a very slight hint of leafy hops in the middle that tries in vain to add some bitterness. The finish has some maple sweetness and a bit more roasted maltiness fading off the tongue. With all this sweetness it is still fairly light on body and thin in texture. Carbonation is light as well and makes the thin texture somewhat slick. For me this beer is way too sweet. I can not help thinking that I should be putting this on pancakes or something. Drinkability for me is very low
column5: as I couldn’t see drinking any more than one of these at a time.

column3: Germany;Helles / Dortmunder Export;Löwenbräu Munich (AB InBev);"500ml bottle brewed in Germany at 5.2%. Shiny clear golden yellow. Decent head
column4: in size and duration. Sweet grassy aroma. Moderate carbonation
column5: feels well-judged. The ""well-judged"" theme runs throughout this beer - interesting to compare to the Spaten lager owned by the same company - that felt somewhat disparate and minimalist
column6: this feels more holistic and minimalist. Here's a grassy
column7: tangy (like citrus without the flavour) hop that melds seamlessly with a light
column9: which at no point becomes sickly. A fine drinker's lager
column10: albeit with little to no interest for the beer connoisseur besides perhaps a one-off tasting. Manages to hit that lager spot quite precisely
column11: while assiduously avoiding the many duff notes of the style - no metal or sweetcorn-juice here
column12: and if there's a slight spicy earthiness
column13: it only serves to elevate the beer. Feels well-crafted
column14: at least in the sense of the makers having had a certain focus on the palate (light
column15: yet in the middle) and succeeding in hitting their mark. What does it really matter that they used hop extract to do it? It's funny how it crops up among the ingredients of certain company-owned brewer's beers
column17: this is a simple but well-judged lager
column19: a fine beer as well as a fine example of the style
column20: although don't expect oodles of flavour. There's ""macro"" and there's ""macro"" - this is the good kind."

Palate: Medium-full body; smooth; still plenty of carbonation. Overall: Damn good

but difficult and hard to describe because it is so complex; I love this beer and I enjoy exploring the differences from year to year (although the 2010 is not good right now)...

A shame really - the flavours and aromas promise a great deal but the lack of carbonation really knocks this one down quite a bit. Bottle sampled at GBBF 2005.

United States;Blonde Ale / Golden Ale;Pabst Brewing Company;"From Oct 2006 Poured from 16oz can a straw gold with a lot of foam that settles down to a fine broken layer. The smell is on the sweet malty side with just a bit of ""lemon pledge"" nose to offset it and that's ok with me. The taste is sweetish malty up front with some graininess and just a wee bit of bitterness right before the finish that could easily get over looked and the finish itself? That's on the watery side and probably the weakest taste feature for this APA. I remember this brew from back in the 70's and 80's and it had a really nice hop bitterness bite to it that threw the flavours totally out of balance but that's what made it so darn tasty. I really miss that old formula but this one is pretty good as well. If I had it in my market
column4: I'd visit it often."
